Award.AwardTitle: OP: Investigating High-K Modes in Metamaterial Structures
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical description: This project addresses the properties of metamaterials - layered structures comprising alternating thin films of electrically conducting and insulating materials. The optical characteristics of these metamaterials depend on the properties of the conductor and the insulator, as well as the structural details of the layers. Metamaterials alter the normal propagation of light, enabling effects like imaging of objects much smaller than the wavelength and backwards bending of light. The overarching goal of this project is to better understand such effects and how they may be harnessed in novel applications. First, the research team is investigating how these metamaterials may be used to focus light into ultra small spots, to enable intense light concentration. Second, light absorbing materials are being placed inside the metamaterial to understand how the unusual light propagation alters their properties. Such structures may enable efficient sensors for environmental gas monitoring. During the summer months, female undergraduate students and a high school intern work together with the research group, to help broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in science. This research is also being used to develop a science education module, to be made available to the local community at various outreach events.

Technical description: The goal of this project is to understand and control light propagation through infrared hyperbolic metamaterials (HMMs). These HMMs comprise alternating layers of doped and undoped semiconductors grown by molecular beam epitaxy. This method enables the growth of crystalline HMMs with low losses, sharp interfaces, high lateral uniformity, tunable optical properties, and atomic control over layer thickness. Light transmission through subwavelength gratings is the first topic of investigation. Near-field imaging is used to examine extreme subwavelength focusing and imaging of subwavelength features. The second topic aims to incorporate quantum wells into the HMM structure. This enables modulation of the overall optical properties of the structure via strong coupling between the quantum well intersubband transition and the HMM optical states. This research develops the fundamental understanding required for the creation of monolithically integrated infrared optical systems based on designer semiconductor HMMs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigates the properties of hyperbolic metamaterials (HMMs) which are layered composite structures comprising alternating thin films of electrically conducting and insulating materials. The optical characteristics of these HMMs depend on the properties of the conductor and the insulator, as well as the structural details of the layers like layer thickness, number of repeats, and the ratio of the conductor to insulator thickness. HMMs alter the normal propagation of light, enabling effects like imaging of objects much smaller than the wavelength and bending light backward enabling a variety of applications, including on-chip routing of light, enhanced sensing, and subwavelength imaging.

The goal of this project is to better understand how the HMM constituents impact the HMM properties. The infrared includes wavelengths of light that are longer than the visible spectral range. The traditional building blocks of HMMs in the visible spectral range like gold and silver do not work in the infrared. This project instead investigated semiconductors as HMM components. In this case, heavily-doped semiconductors act as the conductive metallic layers while undoped semiconductors act as the insulating dielectric layers. These layer stacks can be synthesized using molecular beam epitaxy, an industrially-relevant ultra-high vacuum technique that enables the deposition of materials one atomic layer at a time. This results in crystalline high-quality metamaterial stacks with sharp interfaces between layers and extremely good control over the material properties.

This project began by understanding how the HMM optical properties changed as the semiconductor material was changed. We found that choosing material pairs with large conduction band offsets enabled good confinement of the electrons to the metal layers which is crucial for HMMs. Unlike normal materials, HMMs can support the propagation of light with extremely high wavevectors; these modes are called high-k modes or volume plasmon polariton (VPP) modes. VPP are used for many of the HMM applications noted above. We found that HMMs with large conduction band offsets between the metal and dielectric layers have stronger and less lossy VPP modes.

One of the challenges working with these materials is that the synthesis requirements for the doped metallic layers are very strict. This makes it difficult to grow those layers and difficult to integrate those layers with other materials. We found that adding a very small amount of bismuth during the growth of our doped materials allows us to relax the synthesis requirements and reduces optical losses in the material, both improving the quality of VPP modes and making it easier to integrate doped semiconductor materials with other structures.

In addition to absorbing light, infrared HMMs can also emit light when heated. We used these materials to test a prediction that HMMs should be able to emit more light than expected when heated, a process known as super-Planckian thermal emission. Upon testing this prediction, we found that in our geometry, these materials did not produce super-Planckian thermal emission. We instead observed selective emission corresponding to the wavelengths of the VPP modes.

HMMs are traditionally modeled using the effective medium approximation (EMA). This approximation assumes that the HMM is comprised of an infinite number of infinitely thin layers and that the HMM is bounded by air on both sides. This is clearly not the case in a real HMM deposited on a substrate. We therefore compared the predictions for the VPP mode position from EMA with the predictions from a finite element solver, COMSOL Multiphysics. We discovered that the total HMM thickness has a stronger influence on the position of the VPP modes than the subwavelength structure of the HMM. We also found that the main limitation of EMA is its inability to account for the optical properties of the substrate.

The intellectual merit of this proposal was its use of semiconductor-based HMMs, which allows us to investigate emergent optical phenomena in low-loss crystalline materials. Using semiconductors allows us to isolate the effect of a single variable while keeping others constant, thus enabling a systematic approach to understanding the factors that impact the quality of HMs and improving them. Exploration of subwavelength optical properties is significantly more challenging at visible wavelengths due to the difficulty in fabricating subwavelength features. Furthermore, our MBE-based growth of all-semiconductor HMMs enables the monolithic integration of quantum wells and other III-V semiconductor optoelectronic structures, a structure that cannot be achieved in traditional HMMs.

The broader impacts of this work centered around participation in the University of Delaware high school internship program. A high school intern worked in the lab during the summers of this grant. One intern, for example, built our thermal emission setup, measured the samples, and was a co-author on the resulting paper. The PI participated in summer camps run by the University of Delaware College of Engineering outreach program, though this activity was curtailed by the covid-19 pandemic.
